STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 10, 2022
Janet Vyse-Staszak
Mason-Oceana County DHHS
4081 W. Polk
Hart, MI 49420
RE: License #: CP640201336
Mason-Oceana County DHHS
4081 W. Polk
Hart, MI 49420
Dear Mrs. Vyse-Staszak:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
June 9, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP640201336
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Janet Vyse-Staszak, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Mason-Oceana County DHHS
Facility Address: 4081 W. Polk
Hart, MI 49420

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was provided a renewal application within 60 calendar days of their license
expiration date as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/25/2021
R 400.12324 Reevaluation
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15 calendar
days before the expiration date of the foster home license.
One of three open foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the
licensing recommendation was made to the department at least 15 calendar days
before the expiration date of the foster home license.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
shall complete a written report.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not have a completed written report
within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
4

(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report required
by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
Two of four special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was provided a copy of the report within 10 calendar days of completion as
required.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) Agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a minimum,
include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(II) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical examination
shall be completed within 30 calendar days after placement.
One of six open foster care files reviewed did not have an initial medical examination
completed within 30 calendar days after placement as required.
File one: Initial medical visit was not completed timely; child was removed on
12/15/2021 and initial medical exam completed on 3/1/2022.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/25/2021
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of six open foster care files reviewed contained service plans that were not
completed timely.
File one: USP due on 4/6/2022 was submitted late (4/7/2022).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/26/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/6/2020
6/29/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/25/2021
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least once
every month.
5

Two of six open foster care files reviewed did not have monthly visitation with the
worker and child in the placement as required.
File one: There is no documented home visit with the child in the placement for the
month of June 2021.
File two: There is no documented home visit with the child in the placement for the
month of January 2022.
R 400.12422 Foster care record
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(g) A photograph taken at least annually
One of two closed foster care files reviewed did not contain an updated photograph of
the youth as required.
File one: MISACWIS photo taken on 7/10/2020, case closure on 8/9/2021
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS 69 Foster Care/Juvenile
Justice Action Summary and upload to MISACWIS within the
timeframe required for the specified action/change.
One of six open foster care files reviewed did not have the DHS 69 Action Summary
forms completed as required.
Two of two closed foster care files reviewed did not have the DHS 69 Action Summary
forms completed as required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as outlines in
the following:
6

Five of six open foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.
File one: There is not a corresponding FTM in the case file for 12/9/2021 USP.
File two: There is not a corresponding FTM in the case file for 4/6/2022 USP.
File three: There is not a corresponding FTM for 2/22/2022 USP (1/18/2022 FTM is
too early to count).
File four: There is not a corresponding FTM for 4/13/2022 USP.
File five: There is not a corresponding FTM for 9/1/2021 USP and 11/29/2021 USP.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/26/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/6/2020
6/29/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/25/2021
FOM 722-06B FTM documentation
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to capture
family demographics, FTM logistical information, needs,
strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the safety plan, and
any recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The
DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM. The
caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Four of six open foster care files reviewed did not have the DHS-1105 form or it was
not uploaded timely.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Initial Medical Passport
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must
be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's placement date
to the following:
 Foster care provider.
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's current
and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
7

At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
Three of six open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports as
required.
File one: There are no medical passports between 6/23/2021-3/9/2022.
File two: Initial medical passport was not provided to foster parent within 14 days of
removal. Child was removed on 12/8/2021 and FP signature on medical passport is
dated 2/3/2022.
File three: Initial medical passport not provided timely; child was removed on
12/15/2021 and initial medical passport was provided on 2/10/2022.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/26/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/6/2020 (cited under ISEP 6.49)
6/29/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/25/2021
FOM 722-08D Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
8

Five of eight open foster care files reviewed did not contain all required signatures on
PATP’s or documentation as to why it could not be obtained.
File one: 5/6/2021 PATP caregiver signature not obtained timely and missing mother's
signature; 11/1/2021 PATP missing caregiver signature.
File two: 7/6/2021 PATP missing caregiver, youth, and mother's signature; 10/4/2021
PATP signatures not obtained timely (mother: 11/18/2021, child and foster parent:
11/15/2021), 11/15/2021 PATP missing youth and foster parent signature; 2/14/22
PATP missing mother's signature, child's PATP not uploaded so unable to verify
signatures.
File three: 3/3/2022 PATP missing mother's signature.
File four: 9/23/2021 PATP signatures not obtained timely (11/10/2021).
File five: 7/22/2021 PATP foster parent signature obtained late (8/30/2021); 1/4/2022
PATP not mailed to dad timely (2/14/2022), foster parent not uploaded so unable to
verify signature.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/25/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 All signed documents should include dates of signature.
 Upload PATP page with annotations noted if unable to locate, refused to sign,
etc.
 Social work contacts for special investigations need to be included in the
report. If there are issues inputting contacts, please contact the Help Desk.
 Upload closing SI letter verifying foster parents were provided a copy of the
report timely.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
9

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
interim inspection completed on 6/29/2021 with a corrective action plan approved on
8/25/2021. During the review the agency had sixteen violations. Six citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under review
the agency expressed the impact that the COVID-19 pandemic had on overall
compliance in some areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting some requirements during
this review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated lingering effects of COVID-19
have continued to present some challenges regarding medicals and dentals. In
addition, some face-to-face contacts were not able to be met due illness.
The CA indicated the agency has implemented a number of internal processes as a
result of the previous year CAP. The development of a licensing spreadsheet and
worker/supervisor checklist have been beneficial. Supervisors have increased the
number of case reads as well. The CA also noted staff have taken a more active role
in assuring proper, complete case files. The CA expressed confidence that several
areas will improve over the next review period.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with four staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged there
were some minor challenges related to hybrid/remote schedules but overall felt as
though the agency has adjusted well to changes related to COVID-19. Staff reported
feeling supported by supervisors and co-workers and reported no areas of need.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
____________6/9/2022___________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
10

Approved By:
June 10, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica Vandenheuvel Date
Area Manager
